titleInfo.title: Mental Health Music Therapy with the Hispanic/Latino Community
titleInfo.subTitle: Cultural Identity, Cultural Perspectives, Music Preferences and Repertoire

mods:mods.abstract: The diverse Hispanic/Latino population is the fastest-growing minority in the United States. This community faces specific barriers and multiple inequalities when seeking medical health care in the U.S. Moreover, there are particular challenges to seeking mental health services, such as language barriers, poverty, and cultural perceptions, among others. Music therapists must keep up with the changes in the overall population to ensure providing quality and ethical services to clients who identify as Hispanic or Latino. This research aims to present culturally relevant information to clinicians working with Hispanic or Latino persons. An extensive review of literature was completed, yielding cultural subsections addressing specific issues to be considered from a clinical standpoint. The topics addressed in this research were cultural overview, race taxonomy, identity, language and communication, religion, gender, immigration and generations, and mental health. Music therapists, educators, health care professionals, and individuals who identified as Hispanic or Latino were asked to authenticate this material via an interview process. These participants in this research provided feedback on the cultural subsections and shared their perspectives of commonalities and differences with the information presented. The researcher incorporated the participants' viewpoints into each cultural subsection. The mental health topics discussed in this dissertation followed the structure of the fifth edition of the Diagnostic Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5). The researcher included the DSM-5 suggested Cultural Formulation Interviews (CFI) at the end of each cultural subsection or topic. In addition, an annotated list of songs recommended for counseling-based interventions and a guide of sing-along songs was included as a resource for music therapists. Keywords: Hispanic, Latino, Latinx, music therapy, cultural overview, mental health, DSM-5
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the College of Music in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
cultural overview, DSM-5, Hispanic/Latino, mental health, music therapy, repertoire suggestions
Jayne M. Standley, Professor Directing Dissertation; Bruce Holzman, University Representative; Lori F. Gooding, Committee Member; Kimberly VanWeelden, Committee Member.
